1054746453808009216.text:
Saying "I don't want to ask for feedback right now because I'm not ready to act on it" is an excuse.

There are plenty of ways to act on feedback – to show you're listening, to show you're seriously contemplating the feedback – without actually implementing the idea, itself.

1054744389870731264.text:
"If I ask for feedback, I have to act on it, right?"

Yes... But acting on feedback ≠ implementing the idea, always.

Acting on feedback = Thanking person for speaking up.
Acting on feedback = Explaining why *not* doing smthg. 
Acting on feedback = Saying when you'll decide.

1110923271338381313.text: 6. Lastly, some people aren't skilled writers, but great verbal communicators! While others aren't strong at presenting, but great at writing their thoughts down. Having a variety of avenues to advance your career and share your work is a feature, not a bug.

1110922550975057920.text: 5. Also speaking lets me meet other speakers (many of whom are people I've admired from afar!). Writing is a very solo act, which I also enjoy for that reason.

1110922550140379136.text: 4. Both reach different audiences! Writing typically reaches my direct network and maybe a few rungs outward. Speaking has introduced me/my work/my ideas to folks that have never read a thing I've written.

1110922549385482240.text: 3. Both are similar in terms of PR impact overall, and are useful if you're a hiring manager wanting to promote your company/team. Have had people mention both talks and posts to me when I reach out to recruit them.

1110922548672372738.text: 2. Writing tends to be easier to get started with, and is more durable (more folks read my old posts than watch old talks). But writing also allows for less nuance than speaking (since you're only communicating through text).

1110922547871256582.text:
Getting asked about the value differences between speaking/writing, so, a few thoughts on that:

1. They each offer different levels of engagement. You can't really have a conversation with the author of a blog post after you read it, but in a lot of cases you can with speakers!

1110893241849778176.text: Also, writing and speaking (in my experience) are pretty different in the value they generate, and really shouldn't be compared. Neither is better or worse, just different

1110891396712534016.text:
Speaking at conferences is great if you want to speak about your experiences.

Writing a blog is great if you want to write about your experiences.

Sharing with others, however you do it, is good for your career and our industry.

1085534636053270529.text: I could go on, but I find every time I have this discussion, I can really boil it down to those 4 things. Ditching branches as much as possible is such an operational *and* cultural win if orgs are able to embrace it.

1085534635361255429.text: 4. Pushing your code directly to trunk means that now you need to create resilient deployment systems (this is great!) and also that everyone needs to take full responsibility for the code they write all the way until it becomes available to end users (also great!).

1085534634614669313.text: 3. Branches solve a problem that feature flagging solves way better. Isolate your code from users and other code paths, but now also you get to flag it on for you, your team, your company in production!

1085534633998106624.text: 2. In any environment where code is released to production regularly (more than once a day?), any branch you make is instantaneously a lie. Scale that up to 1 branch per dev in a 200-dev org and  you have 200 lies about the code. Welcome to Merge Conflict City.

1085534633175994368.text:
People are asking for more color on this (you monsters, this is Twitter!), so here goes:

1. Most dev environments are *not* mirrors of production systems. I can't count the number of times in my career I've found bugs or seen a release pulled back because "prod is different."

1085523606359166976.text: My honest opinion (thanks to Etsy) is that branches are evil and should be avoided at all costs.https://twitter.com/emilr/status/1085444040680767488 …

1044554498377744384.text: ”These are our products and we must iterate on them because these are our products,” has not served us as well as we would like to believe.

1044554496897163264.text: Apply that to Instagram. Or Facebook. Or LinkedIn. Or Twitter.

1044554493835259904.text: I think it was @alicedubois who said, “If you have a video team for too long they will see everything only through a video lens. But what if the answer isn’t video?”

1044553561533804544.text: We stopped some things too early, but others it was totally right. How many other products should just stop for awhile? Lots I bet.

1044553559960891392.text: One thing I always admired about BuzzFeed was its ability to just stop when something was “good enough for now.” Being people and time-constrained forced that sort of convo.

1044553558295805952.text: People are worried Instagram will be iterated into the ground with the founders leaving. How many other products were made worse by the endless pursuit of more engagement?

1044553556253192192.text: Something I’ve been thinking about a lot lately: the end of a product. Not the death, but the point at which it’s good enough and iteration should slow or stop entirely.

1025103824904769539.text: So if you find yourself arguing for or against something based on how much time was involved, step back and consider other quality signals in parallel. Time can have meaning, but not always and certainly not by itself.

1025103823092805634.text: But I’ve met people with decades of experience who weren’t as skilled as someone else with more relevant, shorter experience. And I’ve spent a lot of time on projects that proved to be dead ends.

1025103821406711809.text: From hearing teams argue to ship because “we spent three months on this” to job postings with a Years of Experience requirement, people are drawn toward time spent as a meaningful metric.

1025103818965569536.text: I’ve been reflecting lately on the fallacy that time spent on something is, by itself, a signal of quality.
